raw_text:
Robots march to US cinema summit
 
 Animated movie Robots has opened at the top of the US and Canada box office chart, taking $36.5m (£19m) on its first weekend on release.
 
 Featuring the voices of Ewan McGregor, Halle Berry, Robin Williams and Mel Brooks, Robots follows a robot inventor who moves to a big city. Vin Diesel's family comedy The Pacifier fell to the number two spot, taking $18.1m (£9.4m). New Bruce Willis movie Hostage opened at number four with $9.8m (£5.1m).
 
 However, a recut version of Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ, which featured less violence than last year's original movie, took just $239,850 (£125,000), despite opening in 957 cinemas. The new version of the film received little publicity and the original version is available across the US on DVD. "We certainly had higher expectations than what we got," said Rob Schwartz, head of distribution for Newmarket Films, which released The Passion of the Christ. "We were trying to get the film out there, hoping it would reach an audience that it didn't quite reach the first time around. It doesn't seem to have worked out quite as well as we had hoped." Meanwhile, Will Smith comedy Hitch has become the top film at the global box office after taking an estimated $30.1m (£15.6m) over the weekend at cinemas outside North America, according to industry website Screen Daily. It has taken $65.5m (£34.1m) so far, buoyed by opening at number one in the UK last weekend and a successful run in Germany. The movie, which cost a reported $70m (£36.4m) to make, has taken $138m (£72m) in the US so far.
llama3.2:1b: Robots has opened at the top of the US box office chart with $36.5m, ahead of Vin Diesel's film The Pacifier and Will Smith's comedy Hitch.
A recut version of Mel Gibson's Passion of the Christ took just $239,850 worldwide despite receiving little publicity.
llama3.2:3b: Robots opened at US box office with $36.5m, followed by Vin Diesel's family comedy The Pacifier ($18.1m).
A recut version of Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ took $239,850.
Will Smith's Hitch became top film globally with estimated $30.1m outside North America, taking $138m in US and $65.5m globally.
gemma2:2b: Robots topped the US box office for its opening weekend, earning $36.5 million.
The Pacifier and Hostage followed closely behind.
The Passion of the Christ saw a disappointing performance, earning only $239,850 despite widespread release.
Will Smith's Hitch was the top-grossing film globally.

One of its stars was Mel Brooks, who said it didn't work well with people in big cities.

Another movie about a murder, called "The Passion of Christ", also didn't do well - it only earned $239, 850 (£125, 000), and the original version is now available on DVD in North America.

It opened in number one in Britain and had a successful run in Germany.

opencoder:1.5b: Robots march to US cinema summit.
Animated movie Robots has opened at the top of the US and Canada box office chart, taking $36.5m (£19m) on its first weekend on release.
Featuring the voices of Ewan McGregor, Halle Berry, Robin Williams and Mel Brooks, Robots follows a robot inventor who moves to a big city.
Vin Diesel's family comedy The Pacifier fell to the number two spot, taking $18.1m (£9.4m).
New Bruce Willis movie Hostage opened at number four with $9.8m (£5.1m).
However, a recut version of Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ, which featured less violence than last year's original movie, took just $239,850 (£125,000), despite opening in 957 cinemas.
The new version of the film received little publicity and the original version is available across the US on DVD.
"We certainly had higher expectations than what we got," said Rob Schwartz, head of distribution for Newmarket Films, which released The Passion of the Christ.
"We were trying to get the film out there, hoping it would reach an audience that it didn't quite reach the first time around.
It doesn't seem to have worked out quite as well as we had hoped."

Meanwhile, Will Smith comedy Hitch has become the top film at the global box office after taking an estimated $30.1m (£15.6m) over the weekend at cinemas outside North America, according to industry website Screen Daily.
It has taken $65.5m (£34.1m) so far, butoyed by opening at number one in the UK last weekend and a successful run in Germany.
smollm:1.7b: Robots has opened at the top of the US and Canada box office chart on its first weekend, taking $36.5 million (approximately £19 million).
The film features the voices of Ewan McGregor, Halle Berry, Robin Williams, and Mel Brooks, with Vin Diesel's family comedy Hostage also performing well at number two.

However, a recut version of Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ, which featured less violence than last year's original movie, took just $239,850 (approximately £125,000) despite opening in 957 cinemas.
The film received little publicity and the original version is available across the US on DVD.
"We certainly had higher expectations than what we got," said Rob Schwartz, head of distribution for Newmarket Films, which released The Passion of the Christ.
"We were trying to get the film out there, hoping it would reach an audience that it didn't quite reach the first time around."

Meanwhile, Will Smith comedy Hitch has become the top film at the global box office after taking an estimated $30.1 million (approximately £15.6 million) over the weekend at cinemas outside North America.
It has taken $65.5 million (approximately £34.1 million) so far, buoyed by opening at number one in the UK last weekend and a successful run in Germany.
The movie, which cost a reported $70 million (approximately £36.4 million), has taken $138 million (approximately £72 million) in the US so far.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Robots: Animated movie opened US box office with $365m revenue, followed by The Pacifier with $181m.
Hostage opened lower with $240k in the first weekend, despite similar opening.
2014 movie The Passion of the Christ had $239k with less buzz than expected; released on DVD now.
Hitch scored globally over $30m at US box office, top in North America, and in Germany, and its worldwide earnings are still under way.
tinyllama:1.1b: Amazon Prime Video is hosting a series of exclusive premieres for the latest Marvel Studios films under its "Prime Video Theater" banner.
These exclusive screenings feature exclusive bonus content such as deleted scenes, extended sequences, and behind-the-scenes features.
The first two movies in the Phase Three series, Ant-Man and The Winter Soldier, have hit #1 on both the US and Canada box office charts following their premiere exclusively on Prime Video.
Meanwhile, the Passion of the Christ recut version received low publicity and failed to reach its expected audience, with only 957 cinemas screening the film in North America.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Robots, a sci-fi animation released in 2005, has emerged as the top film at the top of the US and Canada box office chart with an estimated $36.5 million in its opening weekend.
The movie features the voices of Ewan McGregor, Halle Berry, and Robin Williams, who play a team of robot inventors who move to the big city for their new company.

Vin Diesel's action comedy The Pacifier also took second place with $18.1 million, while Mel Gibson's film The Passion of the Christ opened at number four with $9.8 million and a recut version of Mel Gibson's The Bible received little publicity and opened in 957 cinemas, making it available across the US on DVD.
phi:2.7b: The new animated movie Robots is the top-grossing film in the United States and Canada with $36.5 million on its first weekend.
It features a star-studded voice cast including Ewan McGregor, Halle Berry, Robin Williams, and Mel Brooks.
In contrast, Bruce Willis' Hostage is at number four with $9.8 million.
However, the recut version of The Passion of the Christ did not do well despite opening in 957 cinemas.
Will Smith's Hitch has become the top film globally taking $30.1 million outside North America after opening at number one in the UK and Germany.
orca-mini:3b: Robots, an animated movie featuring Ewan McGregor, Halle Berry, Robin Williams and Mel Brooks, opened at the top of the US and Canada box office chart with $36.5m (£19m).
The Pacifier, which stars Vin Diesel, dropped to the number two spot.
Hostage, a Bruce Willis movie, opened at number four with $9.8m (£5.1m).

Despite featuring less violence than the original version of Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ, a recut version of the film took just $239,850 (£125,000) in 957 cinemas despite being available on DVD.
The new version of the film received little publicity.

chatgpt-4o-latest: Animated film Robots debuted at number one in the US and Canada box office, earning $36.5 million in its opening weekend.
Featuring voices of Ewan McGregor, Halle Berry, and Robin Williams, it follows a robot inventor in a big city.
The Pacifier dropped to second place with $18.1 million, while Bruce Willis' Hostage opened at number four with $9.8 million.
A recut version of The Passion of the Christ, with reduced violence, performed poorly, earning just $239,850 despite opening in 957 cinemas.
Meanwhile, Will Smith's Hitch became the top global film, earning $30.1 million internationally over the weekend, bringing its total to $138 million in the US and $65.5 million overseas.
stablelm2:1.6b: Robots, an animated film featuring Ewan McGregor, Halle Berry, Robin Williams, and Mel Brooks, debuted at number one in the US and Canada box office chart with $1.5 million on its first weekend of release.
Vin Diesel's family comedy The Pacifier followed at number two with $1 million.
However, a recut version of Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ, featuring less violence, took $1 million, despite opening in fewer theaters than the original movie.
Despite limited publicity for the new version, it became the top film at the global box office after taking an estimated $1.5 million over the weekend at cinemas outside North America.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Robots, an animated film featuring Ewan McGregor, Halle Berry, Robin Williams, and Mel Brooks, led the US and Canada box office with $36.5m on its debut weekend.
The Pacifier, starring Vin Diesel, secured second place at $18.1m, while Hostage, a new Bruce Willis film, opened at number four with $9.8m.
Despite the promotion of a less violent recut version of Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ, it earned only $239,850 in 957 cinemas, failing to meet expectations.

Meanwhile, Will Smith's Hitch surpassed global box office rankings after earning an estimated $30.1m at international cinemas over the weekend and $65.5m worldwide, including a strong UK premiere and German success.
The film has grossed $138m in the US thus far.
